column4: Column 4
What to Do (Exactly)
2–3 hours deep dive; focus onReact component typing.
2–3 hours; huge shift from React 18. Practice building a simple SSR app.
1–2 hours; understand how forms work in RSC world.
1 hour; practice on a "like" button or todo optimistic update.
1 hour; tie into Next.js/ SEO setup.
1–2 hours; critical for Next.js server components.
30 mins; nice quality-of-life improvement.
Revisit in depth; make sure you can explain hook lifecycle & edge cases.
1 hour; practice writing 2–3 custom hooks (useFetch, useLocalStorage, etc).
2 hours; pick one, know it well. Japan jobs mention these often.
1 hour; you know Zustand; just compare tradeoffs vs Redux.
2–3 hours; align with React 19 Server Components.

column2: Next.jsrendering modes(SSR vs SSG vs ISR vs CSR)
column4: 2 hours; be able to design per-route rendering strategy.
1 hour; basic auth/logging use cases.
1 hour; tie into Actions where possible.

column2: REST API design (resource modeling, status codes, pagination)
column4: 1–2 hours; design 2–3 simple APIs (User, Todo, Post CRUD).

column2: Authentication (OAuth2, OpenID Connect, JWT refresh tokens)
column4: 2–3 hours;your fraud/biometric expertise shines here.Prepare stories.

column2: Node.js fundamentals (event loop, async I/O, modules)
column4: 1–2 hours; big-picture understanding, not deep.
1–2 hours; clarify NestJS patterns vs Express simplicity.

column2: Web security (XSS, CSRF, SQLi, CORS, secure cookies)
column4: 1–2 hours; Japan enterprise issecurity‑heavy. Prepare examples.

column2: Testing – unit tests (Jest, Vitest, React Testing Library)
column4: 3–4 hours.Go from 10% → 25% of your time. Write tests for React components.
2–3 hours; build a full Next.js app + write 3–5 e2e tests end-to-end.
1–2 hours; you use it; be ready for schema design questions.
1–2 hours; many Japan roles use Postgres. Practice a complex query or two.

column2: Redis caching (key-value, TTL, cache-aside, design patterns)
column4: 1–2 hours; you use it in fraud projects; explain failure scenarios & refreshes.
1–2 hours; be able to containerize a Next.js app + Node backend.

column2: AWS basics (EC2, S3, SQS/SNS, Secrets Manager, IAM)
column4: 2–3 hours; connect to your production experience.

column2: Git workflows (feature branches, PRs, code review, CI/CD)
column4: 1 hour; you do this; prepare to talk about pipeline design.

column2: Frontend performance (bundle size, code splitting, lazy loading)
column4: 1–2 hours; practice optimizing a slow Next.js page.
1–2 hours; tie into system design chat/notification scenarios.
Skip for now; not required for most Japan roles.
SKIP.No time.
